original_title: Sri Lanka bond, bill yields open lower in wide quotes
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Treasury bonds opened lower Friday and Treasury bills were quoted wide and sharply at open, dealers said, after officials said bills would be excluded from a re-structuring and a bond re-structure would be voluntary.
A 15.09.2029 bond was traded at 28 percent, Friday down from Thursday’s close of 28.75/85 percent. Business was done at 29.00 percent on Thursday.
A 01.07.2025 bond was quoted at 30.25/45 percent on Friday, down from 31.25/30 percent on Thursday.
One year Treasury bills were quoted wide at 20/24 percent against a weighted average yield of 24.31 percent at an auction on Wednesday.
The 3-month security at which is more demand was sold at 25.99 percent.
Sri Lanka rupee opened at 327/330 rupees against the US dollar unchanged from a day earlier.
Sri Lanka’s interest rates had been elevated in the wake of a currency crisis due to fears of domestic debt re-structuring.
Due to a flaw in the International Monetary Funds default workout process, there is no early cut off date for domestic debt re-structure.
Sri Lanka defaulted on its external debt after seven years of monetary instability from flexible inflation targeting and output gap targeting. (Colombo/Mar31/2023
